topicSections.title: Handling Parameters in Custom OpenGL Shader Programs

inlineContent.text: SceneKit provides two ways to integrate custom GPU shader programs into the rendering of your scene: program objects and shader modifiers.

content.text: Use Program Objects to Replace SceneKit Shading

inlineContent.text: For complete control of the vertex and fragment shaders used to render an object, assign an

instance to the object’s program property. A custom program completely replaces all other rendering parameters, including material settings. Your custom program takes inputs from SceneKit and is responsible for all transform, lighting, and shading effects you want it to produce. For details on custom programs, see

content.text: Use Shader Modifiers to Extend SceneKit Shading

inlineContent.text: Shader modifiers are an alternative to entirely replacing SceneKit’s shaders with your own. You can use shader modifiers to, for example:
Parametrically deform the surface of a geometry
Simulate realistic surfaces with complex material properties
Add artistic lighting effects such as cartoon-style shading
Create special effects by post-processing pixels after SceneKit’s shading is complete

A shader modifier is a snippet of source code in the Metal shader language or OpenGL Shader Language (GLSL) that SceneKit injects into its own shader programs at a defined entry point. Because your shader modifiers are additions to SceneKit’s shader program, using shader modifiers leaves SceneKit’s rendering system intact. That is, you can still use material properties, lighting models, and camera effects to affect the rendered image.
You attach a snippet to a
or
object using its

property, associating it with an entry point corresponding to the stage of SceneKit’s shader program that it modifies: geometry, surface, lighting, or fragment. Each entry point defines a context for the associated snippet, with input variables providing SceneKit’s rendering parameters in that stage and output variables that the snippet writes its results to.
For definitions of each entry point and its inputs and outputs, see

The code you provide for a shader modifier must be organized in a specific structure, as illustrated in the example below:

code: // For Metal, a pragma directive and one custom variable on each line:
// For OpenGL, a separate uniform declaration for each custom variable
vec2 sincos(float t) { return vec2(sin(t), cos(t)); }

inlineContent.text: Custom variables declarations.

You can provide your own inputs to a shader modifier by declaring custom variables. Because the syntax differs between Metal and OpenGL shaders, you must include both declarations for your shader modifier to be usable with both rendering technologies. To pass values into custom variables at render time, see
Custom global functions.
If your shader modifier benefits from factoring common code into functions, place their definitions here. If you include custom functions in your snippet, you must place the
directive between your function definitions and the main body of the snippet.
Pragma directives.
As noted above, the
directive separates custom function definitions from the main body of the snippet. If the snippet contains no function definitions, you may omit this directive.

By default, SceneKit automatically uses material properties to determine whether an object should be rendered with partial transparency and uses this information to optimize rendering performance. Use the
or
directive to override SceneKit’s setting.
Code Snippet.
Place the main body of your shader modifier code at the end of the code snippet.

One shader modifier snippet affects both Metal and OpenGL (or OpenGL ES) rendering—SceneKit automatically translates GLSL syntax to Metal shader syntax before inserting your code snippet into its own shader program. (For some simple shader modifiers, SceneKit can insert the same code snippet into either shader language without translation.)

inlineContent.text: Because SceneKit binds values to shader variables using

or
method, or set a target value for a keypath animation, the value must be contained in an Objective-C object. For uniforms of scalar types, you can assign an
object as a value. Assigning a uniform of a vector or matrix type requires an
object containing data of the appropriate type. You can also bind textures to texture samplers using
objects.
Alternatively, you can create an
or

subclass for your custom shadable object and declare properties whose names match those of the uniform variables in your shader. When you assign a value to the property, SceneKit automatically binds it to the corresponding uniform in the shader program. In this case, your properties can use primitive or structure types appropriate to the corresponding Metal or GLSL variables.
